required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Bio-Seal Biopsy Track Plug for Reducing Pneumothorax Rates Post Lung Biopsy Procedure
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective, Randomized, Multi-centered Safety and Efficacy Evaluation of the Bio-Seal Track Plug for Reducing Pneumothorax Rates Post Lung Biopsy

brief_summary.textblock: BS-1053 A Prospective Randomized Multi-Centered Safety and Efficacy Evaluation of the Bio-Seal Biopsy Track Plug for Reducing Pneumothorax Rates Post Lung Biopsy Procedures

detailed_description.textblock: This is a multi-centered, randomized trial in patients receiving lung biopsies. Patients will be randomized to either receive or not receive a Bio-Seal Biopsy Track Plug after a lung biopsy per standard hospital protocol. This study is designed to demonstrate safety and efficacy of the Bio-Seal Biopsy Track Plug in reducing pneumothorax rates post lung biopsy.

primary_outcome.description: Treatment success was defined as the absence of a pneumothorax at each of the three follow-up time periods (0-60 minutes, 24 hours and 30 days).

secondary_outcome.description: A chest tube is the definitive initial treatment of a pneumothorax.

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of Hospital Admissions for Pneumothorax
Incidence of Adverse Events Related to the Procedure and Device Effects
secondary_outcome.description: Anticipated, device-related adverse events that were defined in the original protocol.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Additional Chest X-rays Needed
Participants Discharged Beyond Hospital's Standard of Care
secondary_outcome.description: Current standard of care for hospital discharge varies. Some institutions allow the patient to be discharged after a 3 hour wait. Others allow discharge after an x-ray indicates no pneumothorax. Since this study was randomized with control patients, the time to discharge beyond the hospital's standard of care was recorded to see if a trend for later discharge was apparent. This measure indicates the number of participants who were discharged later than their hospital's standard of care.
Any treatment emergent adverse events (not considered device related by the investigators).

intervention.description: Deployment of the Bio-Seal plug in needle track

facility.name: University of Texas/MD Anderson Cancer Center
Sacred Heart Medical Center & Heart Institute of Spokane

drop_withdraw_reason.title: Lung resection prior to study completion

outcome.title: Participants Discharged Beyond Hospital's Standard of Care
outcome.description: Current standard of care for hospital discharge varies. Some institutions allow the patient to be discharged after a 3 hour wait. Others allow discharge after an x-ray indicates no pneumothorax. Since this study was randomized with control patients, the time to discharge beyond the hospital’s standard of care was recorded to see if a trend for later discharge was apparent. This measure indicates the number of participants who were discharged later than their hospital's standard of care.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
